subject: Re: [junit] Re: How to test console output?
msgSnippet: ... Why do you have to share the same StringWriter for each test? Just create a new one. J. B. Rainsberger, President, Diaspar Software Services Let s write
messageBody:
>So said jxingtang on 2003-07-29 --------------------
>--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Alain Ravet <alain.ravet.list@w...>
>wrote:
>>
>> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>>
>> >1. Don't use System.out in your application directly. Your
>application components should accept a PrintWriter as a parameter
>somewhere.
>> >2. In your tests, substitute a PrintWriter wrapping a StringWriter
>in place of System.out. This is easy to verify.
>> >
>>
>> Without providing any code - :) -, I'd suggest you use AspectJ to
>> implement solution (2) without modifying the orignal code.
>> You would capture all the "System.out.println()" and feed them to a
>> StringWriter that you would use in your tests.
>>
>> If you use IDEA, the eap/under construction version offers -
>partial -
>> AspectJ support.
>>
>> Alain Ravet
>
>A further question for StringWriter manipulation. Since I have to
>test several methods with console output which share the same
>StringWriter wrapped in the PrinterWriter. The problem is how to
>clean up the buffer after one test case. flush() method seems not
>work as expected.

Why do you have to share the same StringWriter for each test? Just create a new one.


J. B. Rainsberger,
